t: Ezekiel 1
Ezekiel’s Vision of God

Now*p it came to pass in the thirtieth year, in the fourth month,*i on the fifth day*i of the month, as I was*i among the captives by the River Chebar, that*i the heavens were opened and I saw visions of God.
On the fifth day*i of the month, which was*i in the fifth year of King Jehoiachin’s captivity,
the word of the Lord*s came expressly to Ezekiel the priest, the son of Buzi, in the land of the Chaldeans by the River Chebar; and the hand of the Lord*s was upon him there.

Then*p I looked, and behold, a whirlwind was coming out of the north, a great cloud with raging fire engulfing itself; and brightness was*i all around it and radiating out of its midst like the color of amber, out of the midst of the fire.
Also from within it came*i the likeness of four living creatures. And this was*i their appearance: they had the likeness of a man.
Each one had four faces, and each one had four wings.
Their legs were*i straight, and the soles of their feet were*i like the soles of calves’ feet. They sparkled like the color of burnished bronze.
The hands of a man were*i under their wings on their four sides; and each of the four had faces and wings.
Their wings touched one another. The*i creatures*i did not turn when they went, but each one went straight forward.

As*p for the likeness of their faces, each*i had the face of a man; each of the four had the face of a lion on the right side, each of the four had the face of an ox on the left side, and each of the four had the face of an eagle.
Thus were*i their faces. Their wings stretched upward; two wings*i of each one touched one another, and two covered their bodies.
And each one went straight forward; they went wherever the spirit wanted to go, and they did not turn when they went.

As*p for the likeness of the living creatures, their appearance was*i like burning coals of fire, like the appearance of torches going back and forth among the living creatures. The fire was bright, and out of the fire went lightning.
And the living creatures ran back and forth, in appearance like a flash of lightning.
Now*p as I looked at the living creatures, behold, a wheel was*i on the earth beside each living creature with its four faces.

The appearance of the wheels and their workings was*i like the color of beryl, and all four had the same likeness. The appearance of their workings was,*i as it were, a wheel in the middle of a wheel.
When they moved, they went toward any one of four directions; they did not turn aside when they went.
As for their rims, they were so high they were awesome; and their rims were*i full of eyes, all around the four of them.
When the living creatures went, the wheels went beside them; and when the living creatures were lifted up from the earth, the wheels were lifted up.
Wherever the spirit wanted to go, they went, because*i there the spirit went; and the wheels were lifted together with them, for the spirit of the living creatures was*i in the wheels.

When those went, these*i went; when those stood, these*i stood; and when those were lifted up from the earth, the wheels were lifted up together with them, for the spirit of the living creatures was*i in the wheels.
The*p likeness of the firmament above the heads of the living creatures was*i like the color of an awesome crystal, stretched out over their heads.
And under the firmament their wings spread*i out*i straight, one toward another. Each one had two which covered one side, and each one had two which covered the other side of the body.

When they went, I heard the noise of their wings, like the noise of many waters, like the voice of the Almighty, a tumult like the noise of an army; and when they stood still, they let down their wings.
A voice came from above the firmament that was*i over their heads; whenever they stood, they let down their wings.

And*p above the firmament over their heads was*i the likeness of a throne, in appearance like a sapphire stone; on the likeness of the throne was*i a likeness with the appearance of a man high above it.

Also from the appearance of His waist and upward I saw, as it were, the color of amber with the appearance of fire all around within it; and from the appearance of His waist and downward I saw, as it were, the appearance of fire with brightness all around.
Like the appearance of a rainbow in a cloud on a rainy day, so was*i the appearance of the brightness all around it. This was*i the appearance of the likeness of the glory of the Lord.*s
Ezekiel Sent to Rebellious Israel
So*p when I saw it,*i I fell on my face, and I heard a voice of One speaking.
Ezekiel 2
And*p He said to me, “Son of man, stand on your feet, and I will speak to you.”
Then the Spirit entered me when He spoke to me, and set me on my feet; and I heard Him who spoke to me.
And He said to me: “Son of man, I am sending you to the children of Israel, to a rebellious nation that has rebelled against Me; they and their fathers have transgressed against Me to this very day.
For they*i are*i impudent and stubborn children. I am sending you to them, and you shall say to them, ‘Thus says the Lord God.’*s
As for them, whether they hear or whether they refuse—for they are*i a rebellious house—yet they will know that a prophet has been among them.

“And*p you, son of man, do not be afraid of them nor be afraid of their words, though briers and thorns are*i with you and you dwell among scorpions; do not be afraid of their words or dismayed by their looks, though they are*i a rebellious house.
You shall speak My words to them, whether they hear or whether they refuse, for they are*i rebellious.
But you, son of man, hear what I say to you. Do not be rebellious like that rebellious house; open your mouth and eat what I give you.”
Now*p when I looked, there was a hand stretched out to me; and behold, a scroll of a book was*i in it.
Then He spread it before me; and there*i was*i writing on the inside and on the outside, and written on it were*i lamentations and mourning and woe.
Ezekiel 3
Moreover*p He said to me, “Son of man, eat what you find; eat this scroll, and go, speak to the house of Israel.”
So I opened my mouth, and He caused me to eat that scroll.
And*p He said to me, “Son of man, feed your belly, and fill your stomach with this scroll that I give you.” So I ate, and it was in my mouth like honey in sweetness.
Then*p He said to me: “Son of man, go to the house of Israel and speak with My words to them.
For you are*i not sent to a people of unfamiliar speech and of hard language, but*i to the house of Israel,
not to many people of unfamiliar speech and of hard language, whose words you cannot understand. Surely, had I sent you to them, they would have listened to you.
But the house of Israel will not listen to you, because they will not listen to Me; for all the house of Israel are*i impudent and hard-hearted.
Behold, I have made your face strong against their faces, and your forehead strong against their foreheads.
Like adamant stone, harder than flint, I have made your forehead; do not be afraid of them, nor be dismayed at their looks, though they are*i a rebellious house.”
Moreover*p He said to me: “Son of man, receive into your heart all My words that I speak to you, and hear with your ears.
And go, get to the captives, to the children of your people, and speak to them and tell them, ‘Thus says the Lord God,’*s whether they hear, or whether they refuse.”
Then*p the Spirit lifted me up, and I heard behind me a great thunderous voice: “Blessed is*i the glory of the Lord*s from His place!”
I*i also heard*i the noise of the wings of the living creatures that touched one another, and the noise of the wheels beside them, and a great thunderous noise.
So the Spirit lifted me up and took me away, and I went in bitterness, in the heat of my spirit; but the hand of the Lord*s was strong upon me.
Then I came to the captives at Tel Abib, who dwelt by the River Chebar; and I sat where they sat, and remained there astonished among them seven days.
Ezekiel Is a Watchman
Now*p it came to pass at the end of seven days that the word of the Lord*s came to me, saying,
“Son of man, I have made you a watchman for the house of Israel; therefore hear a word from My mouth, and give them warning from Me:

When I say to the wicked, ‘You shall surely die,’ and you give him no warning, nor speak to warn the wicked from his wicked way, to save his life, that same wicked man*i shall die in his iniquity; but his blood I will require at your hand.
Yet, if you warn the wicked, and he does not turn from his wickedness, nor from his wicked way, he shall die in his iniquity; but you have delivered your soul.

“Again,*p when a righteous man*i turns from his righteousness and commits iniquity, and I lay a stumbling block before him, he shall die; because you did not give him warning, he shall die in his sin, and his righteousness which he has done shall not be remembered; but his blood I will require at your hand.
Nevertheless if you warn the righteous man*i that the righteous should not sin, and he does not sin, he shall surely live because he took warning; also you will have delivered your soul.”
Then*p the hand of the Lord*s was upon me there, and He said to me, “Arise, go out into the plain, and there I shall talk with you.”
So*p I arose and went out into the plain, and behold, the glory of the Lord*s stood there, like the glory which I saw by the River Chebar; and I fell on my face.
Then the Spirit entered me and set me on my feet, and spoke with me and said to me: “Go, shut yourself inside your house.
And you, O son of man, surely they will put ropes on you and bind you with them, so that you cannot go out among them.
I will make your tongue cling to the roof of your mouth, so that you shall be mute and not be one to rebuke them, for they are*i a rebellious house.

But when I speak with you, I will open your mouth, and you shall say to them, ‘Thus says the Lord God.’*s He who hears, let him hear; and he who refuses, let him refuse; for they are*i a rebellious house.
Ezekiel 4
The Siege of Jerusalem Portrayed
“You*p also, son of man, take a clay tablet and lay it before you, and portray on it a city, Jerusalem.
Lay siege against it, build a siege wall against it, and heap up a mound against it; set camps against it also, and place battering rams against it all around.

Moreover take for yourself an iron plate, and set it as*i an iron wall between you and the city. Set your face against it, and it shall be besieged, and you shall lay siege against it. This will*i be*i a sign to the house of Israel.
“Lie*p also on your left side, and lay the iniquity of the house of Israel upon it. According*i to the number of the days that you lie on it, you shall bear their iniquity.
For I have laid on you the years of their iniquity, according to the number of the days, three hundred and ninety days; so you shall bear the iniquity of the house of Israel.
And when you have completed them, lie again on your right side; then you shall bear the iniquity of the house of Judah forty days. I have laid on you a day for each year.
“Therefore*p you shall set your face toward the siege of Jerusalem; your arm shall*i be*i uncovered, and you shall prophesy against it.
And surely I will restrain you so that you cannot turn from one side to another till you have ended the days of your siege.

“Also*p take for yourself wheat, barley, beans, lentils, millet, and spelt; put them into one vessel, and make bread of them for yourself. During*i the number of days that you lie on your side, three hundred and ninety days, you shall eat it.
And your food which you eat shall*i be*i by weight, twenty shekels a day; from time to time you shall eat it.
You shall also drink water by measure, one-sixth of a hin; from time to time you shall drink.
And you shall eat it as*i barley cakes; and bake it using fuel of human waste in their sight.”
Then*p the Lord*s said, “So shall the children of Israel eat their defiled bread among the Gentiles, where I will drive them.”

So*p I said, “Ah, Lord God!*s Indeed I have never defiled myself from my youth till now; I have never eaten what died of itself or was torn by beasts, nor has abominable flesh ever come into my mouth.”
Then*p He said to me, “See, I am giving you cow dung instead of human waste, and you shall prepare your bread over it.”
Moreover*p He said to me, “Son of man, surely I will cut off the supply of bread in Jerusalem; they shall eat bread by weight and with anxiety, and shall drink water by measure and with dread,
that they may lack bread and water, and be dismayed with one another, and waste away because of their iniquity.
Ezekiel 5
A Sword Against Jerusalem
“And*p you, son of man, take a sharp sword, take it as a barber’s razor, and pass it*i over your head and your beard; then take scales to weigh and divide the hair.*i

You shall burn with fire one-third in the midst of the city, when the days of the siege are finished; then you shall take one-third and strike around it*i with the sword, and one-third you shall scatter in the wind: I will draw out a sword after them.
You shall also take a small number of them and bind them in the edge of your garment.*i
Then take some of them again and throw them into the midst of the fire, and burn them in the fire. From there a fire will go out into all the house of Israel.
“Thus*p says the Lord God:*s ‘This is*i Jerusalem; I have set her in the midst of the nations and the countries all around her.

She has rebelled against My judgments by doing wickedness more than the nations, and against My statutes more than the countries that are*i all around her; for they have refused My judgments, and they have not walked in My statutes.’

Therefore thus says the Lord God:*s ‘Because you have multiplied disobedience*i more than the nations that are*i all around you, have not walked in My statutes nor kept My judgments, nor even done according to the judgments of the nations that are*i all around you’—
therefore thus says the Lord God:*s ‘Indeed I, even I, am*i against you and will execute judgments in your midst in the sight of the nations.
And I will do among you what I have never done, and the like of which I will never do again, because of all your abominations.
Therefore fathers shall eat their*i sons in your midst, and sons shall eat their fathers; and I will execute judgments among you, and all of you who remain I will scatter to all the winds.

‘Therefore,*p as*i I live,’ says the Lord God,*s ‘surely, because you have defiled My sanctuary with all your detestable things and with all your abominations, therefore I will also diminish you;*i My eye will not spare, nor will I have any pity.

One-third of you shall die of the pestilence, and be consumed with famine in your midst; and one-third shall fall by the sword all around you; and I will scatter another third to all the winds, and I will draw out a sword after them.

‘Thus*p shall My anger be spent, and I will cause My fury to rest upon them, and I will be avenged; and they shall know that I, the Lord,*s have spoken it*i in My zeal, when I have spent My fury upon them.
Moreover I will make you a waste and a reproach among the nations that are*i all around you, in the sight of all who pass by.

‘So*p it shall be a reproach, a taunt, a lesson, and an astonishment to the nations that are*i all around you, when I execute judgments among you in anger and in fury and in furious rebukes. I, the Lord,*s have spoken.
When I send against them the terrible arrows of famine which shall be for destruction, which I will send to destroy you, I will increase the famine upon you and cut off your supply of bread.
So I will send against you famine and wild beasts, and they will bereave you. Pestilence and blood shall pass through you, and I will bring the sword against you. I, the Lord,*s have spoken.’”
Ezekiel 6
Judgment on Idolatrous Israel
Now*p the word of the Lord*s came to me, saying:
“Son of man, set your face toward the mountains of Israel, and prophesy against them,

and say, ‘O mountains of Israel, hear the word of the Lord God!*s Thus says the Lord God*s to the mountains, to the hills, to the ravines, and to the valleys: “Indeed I, even*i I, will bring a sword against you, and I will destroy your high places.
Then your altars shall be desolate, your incense altars shall be broken, and I will cast down your slain men*i before your idols.
And I will lay the corpses of the children of Israel before their idols, and I will scatter your bones all around your altars.

In all your dwelling places the cities shall be laid waste, and the high places shall be desolate, so that your altars may be laid waste and made desolate, your idols may be broken and made to cease, your incense altars may be cut down, and your works may be abolished.
The slain shall fall in your midst, and you shall know that I am*i the Lord.*s
“Yet*p I will leave a remnant, so that you may have some*i who escape the sword among the nations, when you are scattered through the countries.

Then those of you who escape will remember Me among the nations where they are carried captive, because I was crushed by their adulterous heart which has departed from Me, and by their eyes which play the harlot after their idols; they will loathe themselves for the evils which they committed in all their abominations.
And they shall know that I am*i the Lord;*s I have not said in vain that I would bring this calamity upon them.”

‘Thus*p says the Lord God:*s “Pound your fists and stamp your feet, and say, ‘Alas, for all the evil abominations of the house of Israel! For they shall fall by the sword, by famine, and by pestilence.
He who is far off shall die by the pestilence, he who is near shall fall by the sword, and he who remains and is besieged shall die by the famine. Thus will I spend My fury upon them.

Then you shall know that I am*i the Lord,*s when their slain are among their idols all around their altars, on every high hill, on all the mountaintops, under every green tree, and under every thick oak, wherever they offered sweet incense to all their idols.

So I will stretch out My hand against them and make the land desolate, yes, more desolate than the wilderness toward Diblah, in all their dwelling places. Then they shall know that I am*i the Lord.’”’”*s
Ezekiel 7
Judgment on Israel Is Near
Moreover*p the word of the Lord*s came to me, saying,
“And you, son of man, thus says the Lord God*s to the land of Israel: ‘An*pn end! The end has come upon the four corners of the land.
Now*ld the end has*i come*i upon you, And*ld I will send My anger against you; I*ld will judge you according to your ways, And*ld I will repay you for all your abominations.
My*ld eye will not spare you, Nor*ld will I have pity; But*ld I will repay your ways, And*ld your abominations will be in your midst; Then*ld you shall know that I am*i the Lord!’*s
“Thus*p says the Lord God:*s ‘A*pn disaster, a singular disaster; Behold,*ld it has come!
An*ln end has come, The*ld end has come; It*ld has dawned for you; Behold,*ld it has come!
Doom*ld has come to you, you who dwell in the land; The*ld time has come, A*ld day of trouble is*i near, And*ld not of rejoicing in the mountains.
Now*ld upon you I will soon pour out My fury, And*ld spend My anger upon you; I*ld will judge you according to your ways, And*ld I will repay you for all your abominations.

‘My*ln eye will not spare, Nor*ld will I have pity; I*ld will repay you according to your ways, And*ld your abominations will be in your midst. Then*ld you shall know that I am*i the Lord*s who strikes.
‘Behold,*ln the day! Behold,*ld it has come! Doom*ld has gone out; The*ld rod has blossomed, Pride*ld has budded.
Violence*ld has risen up into a rod of wickedness; None*ld of them shall*i remain,*i None*ld of their multitude, None*ld of them; Nor*ld shall*i there*i be*i wailing for them.
The*ld time has come, The*ld day draws near. ‘Let*ln not the buyer rejoice, Nor*ld the seller mourn, For*ld wrath is*i on their whole multitude.

For*ld the seller shall not return to what has been sold, Though*ld he may still be alive; For*ld the vision concerns the whole multitude, And*ld it shall not turn back; No*ld one will strengthen himself Who*ld lives in iniquity.
‘They*ln have blown the trumpet and made everyone ready, But*ld no one goes to battle; For*ld My wrath is*i on all their multitude.
The*ld sword is*i outside, And*ld the pestilence and famine within. Whoever*ld is*i in the field Will*ld die by the sword; And*ld whoever is*i in the city, Famine*ld and pestilence will devour him.
‘Those*ln who survive will escape and be on the mountains Like*ld doves of the valleys, All*ld of them mourning, Each*ld for his iniquity.
Every*ld hand will be feeble, And*ld every knee will be as*i weak as*i water.
They*ld will also be girded with sackcloth; Horror*ld will cover them; Shame*ld will*i be*i on every face, Baldness*ld on all their heads.

‘They*ln will throw their silver into the streets, And*ld their gold will be like refuse; Their*ld silver and their gold will not be able to deliver them In*ld the day of the wrath of the Lord;*s They*ld will not satisfy their souls, Nor*ld fill their stomachs, Because*ld it became their stumbling block of iniquity.

‘As*ln for the beauty of his ornaments, He*ld set it in majesty; But*ld they made from it The*ld images of their abominations— Their*ld detestable things; Therefore*ld I have made it Like*ld refuse to them.
I*ld will give it as plunder Into*ld the hands of strangers, And*ld to the wicked of the earth as spoil; And*ld they shall defile it.
I*ld will turn My face from them, And*ld they will defile My secret place; For*ld robbers shall enter it and defile it.
‘Make*ln a chain, For*ld the land is filled with crimes of blood, And*ld the city is full of violence.
Therefore*ld I will bring the worst of the Gentiles, And*ld they will possess their houses; I*ld will cause the pomp of the strong to cease, And*ld their holy places shall be defiled.
Destruction*ld comes; They*ld will seek peace, but there*i shall*i be*i none.
Disaster*ld will come upon disaster, And*ld rumor will be upon rumor. Then*ld they will seek a vision from a prophet; But*ld the law will perish from the priest, And*ld counsel from the elders.

‘The*ln king will mourn, The*ld prince will be clothed with desolation, And*ld the hands of the common people will tremble. I*ld will do to them according to their way, And*ld according to what they deserve I will judge them; Then*ld they shall know that I am*i the Lord!’”*s
Ezekiel 8
Abominations in the Temple

And*p it came to pass in the sixth year, in the sixth month,*i on the fifth day*i of the month, as I sat in my house with the elders of Judah sitting before me, that the hand of the Lord God*s fell upon me there.

Then I looked, and there was a likeness, like the appearance of fire—from the appearance of His waist and downward, fire; and from His waist and upward, like the appearance of brightness, like the color of amber.

He stretched out the form of a hand, and took me by a lock of my hair; and the Spirit lifted me up between earth and heaven, and brought me in visions of God to Jerusalem, to the door of the north gate of the inner court,*i where the seat of the image of jealousy was,*i which provokes to jealousy.
And behold, the glory of the God of Israel was*i there, like the vision that I saw in the plain.
Then*p He said to me, “Son of man, lift your eyes now toward the north.” So I lifted my eyes toward the north, and there, north of the altar gate, was this image of jealousy in the entrance.

Furthermore*p He said to me, “Son of man, do you see what they are doing, the great abominations that the house of Israel commits here, to make Me go far away from My sanctuary? Now turn again, you will see greater abominations.”
So He brought me to the door of the court; and when I looked, there was a hole in the wall.
Then He said to me, “Son of man, dig into the wall”; and when I dug into the wall, there was a door.
And*p He said to me, “Go in, and see the wicked abominations which they are doing there.”
So I went in and saw, and there—every sort of creeping thing, abominable beasts, and all the idols of the house of Israel, portrayed all around on the walls.

And there stood before them seventy men of the elders of the house of Israel, and in their midst stood Jaazaniah the son of Shaphan. Each man had a censer in his hand, and a thick cloud of incense went up.

Then He said to me, “Son of man, have you seen what the elders of the house of Israel do in the dark, every man in the room of his idols? For they say, ‘The Lord*s does not see us, the Lord*s has forsaken the land.’”
And*p He said to me, “Turn again, and*i you will see greater abominations that they are doing.”
So He brought me to the door of the north gate of the Lord’s*s house; and to my dismay, women were sitting there weeping for Tammuz.
Then*p He said to me, “Have you seen this,*i O son of man? Turn again, you will see greater abominations than these.”

So He brought me into the inner court of the Lord’s*s house; and there, at the door of the temple of the Lord,*s between the porch and the altar, were*i about twenty-five men with their backs toward the temple of the Lord*s and their faces toward the east, and they were worshiping the sun toward the east.

And*p He said to me, “Have you seen this,*i O son of man? Is it a trivial thing to the house of Judah to commit the abominations which they commit here? For they have filled the land with violence; then they have returned to provoke Me to anger. Indeed they put the branch to their nose.
Therefore I also will act in fury. My eye will not spare nor will I have pity; and though they cry in My ears with a loud voice, I will not hear them.”
Ezekiel 9
The Wicked Are Slain
Then*p He called out in my hearing with a loud voice, saying, “Let those who have charge over the city draw near, each with*i a deadly weapon in his hand.”

And suddenly six men came from the direction of the upper gate, which faces north, each with his battle-ax in his hand. One man among them was*i clothed with linen and had a writer’s inkhorn at his side. They went in and stood beside the bronze altar.

Now*p the glory of the God of Israel had gone up from the cherub, where it had been, to the threshold of the temple. And He called to the man clothed with linen, who had*i the writer’s inkhorn at his side;

and the Lord*s said to him, “Go through the midst of the city, through the midst of Jerusalem, and put a mark on the foreheads of the men who sigh and cry over all the abominations that are done within it.”
To*p the others He said in my hearing, “Go after him through the city and kill; do not let your eye spare, nor have any pity.

Utterly slay old and*i young men, maidens and little children and women; but do not come near anyone on whom is*i the mark; and begin at My sanctuary.” So they began with the elders who were*i before the temple.
Then He said to them, “Defile the temple, and fill the courts with the slain. Go out!” And they went out and killed in the city.

So*p it was, that while they were killing them, I was left alone;*i and I fell on my face and cried out, and said, “Ah, Lord God!*s Will You destroy all the remnant of Israel in pouring out Your fury on Jerusalem?”

Then*p He said to me, “The iniquity of the house of Israel and Judah is*i exceedingly great, and the land is full of bloodshed, and the city full of perversity; for they say, ‘The Lord*s has forsaken the land, and the Lord*s does not see!’
And as for Me also, My eye will neither spare, nor will I have pity, but*i I will recompense their deeds on their own head.”
Just*p then, the man clothed with linen, who had*i the inkhorn at his side, reported back and said, “I have done as You commanded me.”
Ezekiel 10
The Glory Departs from the Temple
And*p I looked, and there in the firmament that was above the head of the cherubim, there appeared something like a sapphire stone, having the appearance of the likeness of a throne.

Then He spoke to the man clothed with linen, and said, “Go in among the wheels, under the cherub, fill your hands with coals of fire from among the cherubim, and scatter them*i over the city.” And he went in as I watched.
Now*p the cherubim were standing on the south side of the temple when the man went in, and the cloud filled the inner court.

Then the glory of the Lord*s went up from the cherub, and*i paused*i over the threshold of the temple; and the house was filled with the cloud, and the court was full of the brightness of the Lord’s*s glory.
And the sound of the wings of the cherubim was heard even*i in the outer court, like the voice of Almighty God when He speaks.
Then*p it happened, when He commanded the man clothed in linen, saying, “Take fire from among the wheels, from among the cherubim,” that he went in and stood beside the wheels.

And the cherub stretched out his hand from among the cherubim to the fire that was*i among the cherubim, and took some*i of*i it*i and put it*i into the hands of the man*i clothed with linen, who took it*i and went out.
The cherubim appeared to have the form of a man’s hand under their wings.
And*p when I looked, there were four wheels by the cherubim, one wheel by one cherub and another wheel by each other cherub; the wheels appeared to*i have*i the color of a beryl stone.
As*i for*i their appearance, all four looked alike—as it were, a wheel in the middle of a wheel.
When they went, they went toward any*i of*i their four directions; they did not turn aside when they went, but followed in the direction the head was facing. They did not turn aside when they went.
And their whole body, with their back, their hands, their wings, and the wheels that the four had, were*i full of eyes all around.
As for the wheels, they were called in my hearing, “Wheel.”
Each*p one had four faces: the first face was*i the face of a cherub, the second face the face of a man, the third the face of a lion, and the fourth the face of an eagle.
